response: President-elect Donald Trump has welcomed FBI Director Christopher Wray's resignation, viewing it as an opportunity to end what he describes as the "weaponization" of the FBI against him. Wray announced he would leave his position in January, after serving seven years of a ten-year term initiated by his appointment by Trump in 2017. Trump has nominated Kash Patel, whom he praises as highly qualified, to replace Wray. Patel has an extensive background in counterterrorism and national security. Until Patel's appointment, Deputy Director Paul Abbate will serve as acting director. This move is part of Trump's plan to restore what he calls "Law, Order, and Justice" in the U.S.
